Volatility of Food Prices

Max Roser [cite]
OWID presents work from many different people and organizations. When citing this entry, please also cite the original data source. This entry can be cited as:

Max Roser (2016) – ‘Volatility of Food Prices’. Published online at OurWorldInData.org. Retrieved from: https://ourworldindata.org/volatility-of-food-prices/ [Online Resource]

The volatility of food prices matters very much for the wellbeing of people, but the reason why is not as straightforward as with other topics discussed in this database. For this reason this entry has a slightly different structure than the others. First I’ll try to persuade you that a low volatility of food prices matters very much for people – especially poor people. And only then will I look at the long-term change of the food price volatility. The last two sections are (as usual) about correlates and consequences and about data availability and quality.

# Consequences of High Food Price Volatility

# Volatility of real wages of laborers in Stockholm/Sweden, 1468–2004, measured as the percentage year-on-year change in real wages – Söderberg (2010)1

# Real wages of unskilled laborers in Stockholm, 1365-1864, and industrial workers in Sweden, 1865–2004 (index 1950=100) – Söderberg (2010)2

# Volatility of the deflator consumer price index (CPI), 1291-2004, measured as the percentage year-on-year change in the CPI – Söderberg (2010)3

 

# Volatility in real wages and in the deflator consumer price index (CPI), 1291–2004, measured as the standard deviation of the percentage year-on-year change – Söderberg (2010)4

PeriodVolatility of real wagesVolatility of deflator CPI
1291 - 139938.1
1400 - 9917.8
1500 - 992019.2
1600 - 9916.414.7
1700 - 9913.312.6
1800 - 999.56.9
1900 - 20044.77

 

# Domestic food price volatility by level of economic development, 2000 and 2010 – FAO (2013)5

# Long Run Evidence of the Decrease of Volatility

#  Year-to-year variation in the price of wheat in pisa, 1351-1799 – Ó Gráda6

# Coefficients of variation for wheat and rye combined – market integration in the North and Baltic Seas, 1500-1800 – Jacks (2000)7

 

 

# Correlates, Determinants & Consequences

# Evidence of the Increase of Food Trade and the Effect of Trade on Food Price Volatility

# Average distance of world wheat production from London, 1866-1930 – Olmstead & Rhode (2007)8

 

# Anglo-American wheat Trade, volume and price, 1800-2000 – O’Rourke & Williamson (2005)9

In the following graph you see two important aspects: Firstly the correlation between price correlation and distance and, secondly, how in India between 1750-1830 and 1870-1914 the agricultural market became more integreated, and the price differences between different regions were reduced.

# Market integration in Japan, Indonesia and India – average correlation coefficient vs. distance, 1750-1914 – Van Zanden (2009)10

Excursion: Kerala Study of the Effect of Mobile Phone Adoptions on Price Volatility – The Digital Provide

# Mobile phone adoption by fishermen – Jensen (2007)11

# Prices and mobile phone service in Kerala – Jensen (2007)12

# The Effect of Protectionism

# Decomposition of ‘world’ price variance, 1830-1913 – Federico and Persson (2007)13

# Data Sources

For data on food price volatility check the data section in the food price entry.

Footnotes

  1. This is taken from Söderberg (2010) – Long-term trends in real wages of labourers. In Rodney Edvinsson, Tor Jacobson och Daniel Waldenström (eds.) (2010) – Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008. Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008.
    The article by Söderberg is online at the Swedish Riksbank here.
    The entire book is also available at the Swedish Riksbank here.

  2. This is taken from Söderberg (2010) – Long-term trends in real wages of labourers. In Rodney Edvinsson, Tor Jacobson och Daniel Waldenström (eds.) (2010) – Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008. Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008.

    The article by Söderberg is online at the Swedish Riksbank here.

    The entire book is also available at the Swedish Riksbank here.

    Note by the authors: A vertical line marks the change in 1865 from unskilled labourers in Stockholm to industrial workers in Sweden.

  3. This is taken from Söderberg (2010) – Long-term trends in real wages of labourers. In Rodney Edvinsson, Tor Jacobson och Daniel Waldenström (eds.) (2010) – Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008. Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008.
    The article by Söderberg is online at the Swedish Riksbank here.
    The entire book is also available at the Swedish Riksbank here.

  4. This is taken from Söderberg (2010) – Long-term trends in real wages of labourers. In Rodney Edvinsson, Tor Jacobson och Daniel Waldenström (eds.) (2010) – Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008. Historical Monetary and Financial Statistics for Sweden: Exchange Rates, Prices, and Wages, 1277-2008.
    The article by Söderberg is online at the Swedish Riksbank here.
    The entire book is also available at the Swedish Riksbank here.

  5. The source is the FAO (2013) – Statistical Yearbook, online here.

  6. This is taken from Ó Gráda (2007) – Making Famine History. Journal of Economic Literature. Vol. 45, No. 1 (Mar., 2007), pp. 5-38.
    Online here at the Research Repository from the University College Dublin.
    As noted at the pdf the paper is licensed under Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 3.0 Ireland.

  7. This is taken David S. Jacks (2000) – Market Integration in the North and Baltic Seas, 1500-1800. Department of Economic History. London School of Economics.

    The paper is online here.

     

    The coefficient of variation is defined as the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean.

  8. This is taken from Alan L. Olmstead and Paul W. Rhode – ‘Biological Globalization’ in Hatton, O’Rourke, and Taylor (ed.) (2007) – New Comparative Economic History: Essays in Honor of Jeffrey G. Williamson. MIT Press.

  9. This is taken from O’Rourke & Williamson (2005) – From Malthus to Ohlin: Trade, Industrialisation and Distribution Since 1500. Journal of Economic Growth. March 2005, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 5-34.

    Online here at the Journal of Economic Growth and here at the University of Oxford.

  10. This is taken from Van Zanden (2009) – The Long Road to the Industrial Revolution. Brill Academic Publishers. The book’s website at the publisher is here.

    The original sources of the author are: Studer (2008), Shuie and Keller (2007), and own calculations based on Iwahashi (1981) rice price data in annual Colonial Reports of Indonesia (Indisch Verslag, 1878–1896)

  11. This is taken from Jensen (2007) – The Digital Provide: Information (Technology), Market Performance, and Welfare in the South Indian Fisheries Sector. In The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 122, 3, 879–924.

    Online here at The Quarterly Journal of Economics website.
    Here is an overview of several available versions of this paper.
    And here are the slides on this paper at Yale University.

  12. This is taken from Jensen (2007) – The Digital Provide: Information (Technology), Market Performance, and Welfare in the South Indian Fisheries Sector. In The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 122, 3, 879–924.

    Online here at The Quarterly Journal of Economics website.
    Here is an overview of several available versions of this paper.
    And here are the slides on this paper at Yale University.

  13. This is taken from Giovanni Federico and Karl Gunnar Persson (2007) – ‘Market Integration and Convergence in the World Wheat Market’ in Hatton, O’Rourke, and Taylor (ed.) (2007) – New Comparative Economic History: Essays in Honor of Jeffrey G. Williamson. MIT Press.

Our World in Data

Our World in Data is an online publication by Max Roser which explores the development of human living conditions at a global scale. Our work is licensed under CC BY-SA and freely usable by everyone (including journalists, authors, bloggers, lecturers, or educators).
